documents.content: The roar behind the pitcher told him what the crowd wanted: a strike. He could end this game now, in the bottom of the ninth inning, if he threw just one more strike. But instead he threw a pitch that the batter swung for, desperately. The ball sailed towards first base just outside the foul line—and a million eyes watched, knowing the game would end if only the first baseman caught it. “That was me,” Joe said, watching a replay on the restaurant’s television, five years later. The pitcher, Larry, sat beside him, watching the famous play again. It showed Joe running furiously, stretching with his glove as the camera zoomed in. Joe was perfectly positioned to make the catch, but somehow the ball whizzed past his glove, then bounced limply towards the wall. The next pitch, the batter doubled in two runs to win the game. “The bases were loaded,” muttered Larry, though they both remembered it perfectly well. Larry grabbed a handful of potato chips. His old first baseman, Joe, liked to meet on the anniversary of their last Major League game—the playoff game where they’d lost their chance to play in the World Series. They’d both retired after that loss. Their get-together this year to commemorate the day was especially poignant, as the following morning, their old stadium would be torn down. Each year they’d watch whatever game was on, and every so often the “historic highlights” would include their famous flubbed play. The TV show switched to footage of the announcers laughing at the play. “Talk about unlucky!” one fat sportscaster chuckled. Larry silently grabbed another handful of potato chips. “Does it ever bother you?” Joe asked. Larry stared back at him, then finally said, “No. Not anymore. Not since I heard about the coach’s wife and the legend of the million dollar mitts.” He washed down the potato chips, and then waited for Joe to agree. But Joe surprised him by saying he’d never met Mrs. Williams, and hadn’t heard the legend of the million dollar mitts. “Coach Williams loved the team—you know that. After we lost that game, I saw him getting on a bus for Texas. He was going to ride all night just to watch a college player who he thought might have potential for the next season. But his wife, Mrs. Williams, didn’t go with. She didn’t care about the team like he did. In fact, she was betting AGAINST us. And when I didn’t throw a strike, and you dropped that foul, she made a fortune.” “But gambling is illegal,” Joe said with horror. “Especially if you’re connected to the team! The coach could’ve lost his job and maybe even gone to prison!” “Mrs. Williams knew that,” Larry said. “She learned her lesson later that night, when the police surrounded her private cottage by the lake while everyone else was watching replays of the game. “Did she go to prison?” Joe asked. “They saw a gambler named Roderick arriving with a briefcase full of money. As soon as he’d left, they closed in and banged on her door. I always wondered who tipped them off, but somehow they knew she’d just received a million dollars due to betting on the game. “She finally opened the door,” Larry said, a sad look on his face. “But then they never found the money. All they found was a crate of the team’s baseball mitts that she was donating to a charity auction. The crate was sealed, and it looked like it couldn’t have been opened in the time after the police knocked on the door, so they assumed the money couldn’t be hidden inside. “The police chased after Roderick, and caught him within ten minutes. But when they came back Mrs. Williams was gone, and so was the crate.” “Mrs. Williams must’ve hidden the money inside!” Joe said. “But she never collected it,” Larry finished. “They caught up with her twenty minutes later, without the crate. They figured she’d hidden it, and planned to follow her for the next week. But she died in a bus accident the very next morning, as she was walking back to her house—she’d never learned how to drive. Wherever she hid that crate of baseball mitts, maybe the money is still sitting inside.” The fat announcer on TV looked like he was laughing at Joe again. “But one police officer overheard Mrs. Williams making a phone call that night,” Larry continued. “Unfortunately, he could only make out one sentence: The money’s buried at home.” “Was she talking about the place she lived with Coach Williams?” Joe asked. “She had her private cottage by the lake, but she and coach lived together in a big yellow house nearby, didn’t they?” “They searched the Coach’s house from top to bottom. And you can bet they searched for fresh holes, trying desperately to find the missing crate. But they never did.” “Maybe it wasn’t at the coach’s house,” a strange voice said behind them. They turned to see a thin man with long white hair and a smile on his face. The two ball players recognized him immediately. Five years ago, he’d painted the white lines on the baseball field. It was Gary, the groundskeeper. “You remember Gary, right?” Joe asked. “I invited him to meet us here tonight—poor guy can’t spend every night alone in that empty ballpark. And his timing is perfect! He can keep you company while I run home to check on my wife.” “But I know where the crate is!” said Gary. “I saw something strange that night, and now it all makes sense … “No one ever stayed late at the stadium, except sometimes Coach Williams. But around midnight that night, someone walked right through the locker room, lugging a huge crate. I didn’t see the person’s face, but the security guard told me he’d waved him in as someone he recognized. He was told that the crate was full of equipment to preserve the stadium’s dirt. That person walked straight across the diamond, and then dug up the ground near the batting cage.” “Don’t you see,” said Larry, excitedly. “They buried the money at home. Home plate!” “I’ve checked that field every night, and no one’s ever come around since to dig it up,” Gary continued. “Roderick was sent to jail the next week,” Larry added. “Once the police picked him up, they found he was wanted for other crimes.” The three men looked at each other for a moment. Then without saying a word, they all ran frantically out of the restaurant. “Let’s take my car!” shouted Gary. “No, let’s take mine,” said Joe, “I’ve got shovels!” At the stadium, at home base, the three men began digging furiously. The dirt was firm, but the men were determined, and dug deeper and deeper into the ground. Twenty minutes later, they’d found nothing. But then Joe’s shovel suddenly struck something in the ground that made a suspicious crunching sound. The three men moved to Joe’s side of the hole, and began digging again. It was a wooden surface, the long lid of a buried crate. They cleared away the dirt, and dug a few inches down the side. Without waiting, Gary wedged the shovel under the lid, and used its handle like a lever. The lid popped off, and the three men peered inside. There were twenty baseball mitts, like giant empty hands, now covered with stadium dirt. And next to the mitts was a pile of rectangular paper. Joe reached in and grabbed a handful. It was money: bundles and bundles of money. “And I’ve got some more good news,” said Larry. “I know who buried it here.”

original_metadata.answer_options: (a) Coach Williams; (b) Joe; (c) Mrs. Williams; (d) Roderick
original_metadata.reveal_text:
“Her accomplice was obviously Roderick,” Joe said.
“It couldn’t have been—the security guard said it was someone he’d recognized,” Gary pointed out. “He wouldn’t have let a stranger like Roderick onto the field.”
“Do you think it was Coach Williams?” Joe asked.
“It couldn’t be our coach,” Larry said. “I told you I watched him catch a bus for Texas that same night. So he wouldn’t be around to bury the crate.”
“But the guard would have recognized Mrs. Williams!” Joe suggested. “Maybe she did this alone!”
“Mrs. Williams couldn’t drive,” Gary said. “So she couldn’t deliver that crate from her cottage to the stadium.”
“But then who?” asked Joe.
“I said I’d always wondered who tipped off the police,” said Larry. “Roderick or Mrs. Williams wouldn’t want that. Someone else must’ve been involved in their bet.
“And I always wondered why she’d bet so much in the first place. Unless her accomplice was going to make sure she won.”
Joe stood up straight and puffed up his chest. “Are you accusing me of dropping that ball on purpose?”
“That was the first clue. But tonight, the last night before they tear down the stadium, you invited the man who watches the grounds to join us—for the first time since we started our yearly get-together—at the restaurant, and then tried to leave as soon as he arrived. You even had shovels in your car!”
“And he knew exactly where to dig,” added Gary.
“You’re a crook,” Larry said, “but in a way, I’m relieved. Every night for the last five years, I’ve felt guilty that the team lost that game. But now I know why.”
Joe stared back with a guilty smile, and said, “I guess my unlucky streak isn’t over yet.”

“Do you think it was Coach Williams?” Joe asked.
“It couldn’t be our coach,” Larry said. “I told you I watched him catch a bus for Texas that same night. So he wouldn’t be around to bury the crate.”
“But the guard would have recognized Mrs. Williams!” Joe suggested. “Maybe she did this alone!”
“Mrs. Williams couldn’t drive,” Gary said. “So she couldn’t deliver that crate from her cottage to the stadium.”
“But then who?” asked Joe.
“I said I’d always wondered who tipped off the police,” said Larry. “Roderick or Mrs. Williams wouldn’t want that. Someone else must’ve been involved in their bet.
“And I always wondered why she’d bet so much in the first place. Unless her accomplice was going to make sure she won.”
Joe stood up straight and puffed up his chest. “Are you accusing me of dropping that ball on purpose?”
“That was the first clue. But tonight, the last night before they tear down the stadium, you invited the man who watches the grounds to join us—for the first time since we started our yearly get-together—at the restaurant, and then tried to leave as soon as he arrived. You even had shovels in your car!”
“And he knew exactly where to dig,” added Gary.
“You’re a crook,” Larry said, “but in a way, I’m relieved. Every night for the last five years, I’ve felt guilty that the team lost that game. But now I know why.”
Joe stared back with a guilty smile, and said, “I guess my unlucky streak isn’t over yet.”

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1.  Motive  
   •  Whoever profited from the million-dollar wager must have been certain the team would lose, therefore had to be in a position to influence the game.  
   •  Mrs. Williams wanted money, but she could not influence play on the field and she already had an illegal-betting partner (Roderick).  
   •  A player who could deliberately mis-play the ball had a perfect, direct way to guarantee the loss and would share in the winnings.

2.  Opportunity for burying the crate  
   •  The security guard waved the person in because he recognized him.  
   •  The person carried a heavy crate across the diamond close to midnight. Only someone who moved comfortably around the park and could explain himself would be allowed that freedom.  
   •  Mrs. Williams could not drive, so she could not haul a large crate from the lake cottage to the stadium.  
   •  Coach Williams was provably on an overnight bus to Texas.  
   •  Roderick was unknown to the guard.  
   •  The groundskeeper Gary was already on the premises; if he had been the carrier the guard would not have described him as someone arriving with a crate.  
   •  Larry (the pitcher) had no reason to carry equipment: his own pitching error would have produced an immediate win, so he would not have endangered the club’s victory by throwing the hittable pitch in the first place.  
   •  Joe, the first baseman, drove a car (he brought shovels in it), was a well-known face to the guard, could walk naturally with “team equipment,” and had the strongest motive—he alone mis-played the decisive ball.

3.  Physical / circumstantial evidence tonight  
   •  Joe produced shovels from his trunk—he was already equipped to dig the very night before demolition.  
   •  Joe tried to leave the restaurant as soon as Gary, the watchdog of the field, arrived.  
   •  Joe is the only person whose presence five years ago would have satisfied every part of the guard’s description.

4.  Logical chain  
   a.  Mrs. Williams accepted the betting money from Roderick and hid it inside a crate of team mitts (the “million-dollar mitts”).  
   b.  Joe tipped police to divert suspicion, collected the crate, drove it to the park, and said it held “equipment to preserve the stadium’s dirt” (an explanation only a player could deliver credibly).  
   c.  He buried it literally “at home”—home plate—fulfilling Mrs. Williams’s overheard phrase.  
   d.  By eliminating both partners (Mrs. Williams arrested then killed accidentally; Roderick jailed) Joe hoped eventually to recover the money alone.  
   e.  Facing demolition of the field the next morning, he invited the groundskeeper out, intending to slip away and dig unobserved.  
   f.  Gary’s account and Larry’s deductions unmasked him.

Therefore the only person who fits every fact is Joe, the former first-baseman.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Joe (first-baseman), Larry (pitcher), Coach Williams, Mrs. Williams, Gary (groundskeeper), Roderick (gambler)
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Joe  ― the retired first-baseman (surname not given)
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
•  Before the playoff game Mrs. Williams, desperate for fast money, agreed with gambler Roderick to bet heavily that the favored home team would lose.  
•  Needing insurance, she enlisted first-baseman Joe, promising him a share if he guaranteed the defeat.  
•  Joe purposely let the foul pop escape his glove; the batter subsequently drove in the winning runs.  
•  After the game Roderick delivered Mrs. Williams’s million-dollar payoff at her lakeside cottage.  
•  Joe arrived, hid the cash among twenty baseball mitts in a team crate, and phoned police to divert suspicion from himself and to frighten Mrs. Williams into silence.  
•  While officers questioned her, Joe drove the sealed crate to the stadium; the security guard recognized him and let him enter with “maintenance equipment.”  
•  Close to midnight Joe dug a hole beside home plate and buried the “million-dollar mitts,” satisfied that no one would suspect a freshly repaired spot on infield dirt.  
•  Roderick was arrested shortly afterward on unrelated warrants; Mrs. Williams died in a traffic accident the next morning, leaving Joe sole owner of the secret.  
•  For five years the stash lay untouched while Joe and Larry met annually.  
•  Learning that the stadium would be demolished at dawn, Joe hurriedly invited Gary out so the grounds would be unwatched, stocked his car with shovels, and planned to retrieve the money.  
•  Gary’s decades of routine inspection and Larry’s recollection of that night’s oddities led them jointly to the exact spot and, once the crate emerged, to the realization that Joe had been the inside man all along.  
•  Confronted by the evidence—and by his own ill-timed preparations—Joe confessed.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
•  Larry (pitcher): On the mound he could have ended the game with a strike; instead he threw a hittable ball that still should have been an easy foul out. He left the park after the loss, ate with family, and later watched Coach Williams board a bus for Texas. He neither profited nor had access to Mrs. Williams’s cottage.  
•  Coach Williams: Confirmed to be on an overnight bus at the critical time; the guard’s statement requires someone arriving at the stadium, not leaving town.  
•  Mrs. Williams: Supplied the money but could not drive the heavy crate to the stadium and was under police attention during the burial window.  
•  Gary (groundskeeper): Saw the crate being buried, proving he was not the person doing it. Moreover, the guard recognized the carrier as someone arriving, whereas Gary was already inside.  
•  Roderick: Stranger to stadium staff; the guard would never have waved him onto the diamond. He was arrested soon afterward and never free again to recover the money.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
